title: A Wholesome Valentine‚Äôs Day
text:
Looking for Inspiration!
In the spirit of the day characterized by cherubs, candy, and couples, I wanted to ask LLMs for cute ideas to use for children‚Äôs cards this Valentine‚Äôs Day. While I thought my question was rather straightforward, I was surprised (as I‚Äôm sure I often will be through this blog) to see drastically different responses.

title: A Wholesome Valentine‚Äôs Day
text:
Our Goal
My intention with this exploration was to prompt the LLMs to create several family-friendly jokes to write in Valentine‚Äôs day cards. While I always associate cards with some kind of one-liner‚Äì especially on holidays such as VDay‚Äì I came to find out that some chatbots might need slightly more specific instructions than others.
The prompt I used for every case was:






PROMPT: ‚ÄúPlease give me Valentine‚Äôs Day card ideas appropriate for kids!‚Äù







LLM 1: ChatGpt/ GPT-3.5
Of course! Here are some cute and kid-friendly Valentine‚Äôs Day card ideas:

Animal Pals: Create cards featuring adorable animals like cats, dogs, or pandas holding hearts or flowers with messages like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre purr-fect!‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm wild about you!‚Äù
Emoji Love: Design cards with popular emojis expressing love and friendship, such as heart eyes üòç, hugs ü§ó, or smiling faces üòä, with captions like ‚ÄúYou make my heart smile!‚Äù
Superhero Love: Craft cards with superhero themes, using phrases like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my superhero!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou have the power to make my heart soar!‚Äù
Dino-Mite Valentine: Draw dinosaurs holding hearts or wearing heart-shaped sunglasses with puns like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre dino-mite!‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm roarsomely glad you‚Äôre my friend!‚Äù
Space Explorers: Create cards with space themes featuring rockets, planets, and cute aliens, with messages like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre out of this world!‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm over the moon for you!‚Äù
Sweet Treats: Design cards shaped like ice cream cones, cupcakes, or donuts with sprinkles, with sayings like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sweeter than candy!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the sprinkles to my day!‚Äù
Sports Fans: Make cards featuring sports equipment like basketballs, soccer balls, or baseball gloves, with phrases such as ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a slam dunk friend!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou hit a home run in my heart!‚Äù
Magical Unicorns: Create cards with unicorns and rainbows, with messages like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one of a kind!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou make life magical!‚Äù
Under the Sea: Design cards with sea creatures like fish, dolphins, or seahorses, with puns like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre fintastic!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre o-fish-ally awesome!‚Äù
DIY Scratch-off Cards: Make homemade scratch-off cards using metallic paint and dish soap, revealing messages like ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a gem!‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my shining star!‚Äù when scratched off.

Remember to keep the designs colorful, cheerful, and age-appropriate for the kids you‚Äôre making them for. Have fun crafting these Valentine‚Äôs Day cards!






GPT-3.5 Observations




ChatGPT was particularly helpful with thinking of themes and the puns that I typically associate with the Valentine‚Äôs Day cards I would make in elementary school. Providing an example line for each idea was exactly what I wanted from the prompt.
I noticed that when I tried this prompt at different times with ChatGPT, the answer was completely the same and was centered around the same ten ideas. I wonder was this says about the training the chatbot goes through, and would like to note this for a future post about repetition/replication of responses within ChatGPT for the same prompt.
In its standard way, ChatGPT was sure to further humanize itself at the end of the response by adding a sort of conclusion line tying its answer back into my initial query, specifically mentioning the ‚Äúage-appropriate‚Äù nature of the cards. I think this is a defining characteristic of this specific platform; its intention to make itself seem like a helpful, personified assistant rather than a computer program that just spits out answers.

Co-Pilot Observations




This was my first time using Co-Pilot, and I was immediately interested in the sources it provided at the end of its response. Such an addition seems to be a potential solution to the claim that AI is rooted in plagiarism/steals the works of others, and I‚Äôll be curious to see if this is always the case with Co-Pilot.
Another immediate call out is that this platform did not respond with a particularly coherent set of ideas. It did not group by theme or card-type, but rather blended several ideas within its list, leaving the user with someone disjointed answers like ‚ÄúSuperhero Tootsie Roll Pop Valentines‚Äù or ‚ÄúOrigami Heart Cards.‚Äù Additionally, unlike ChatGPT, it left the user on its own on several occasions, saying things like, ‚Äúwrite a sweet message inside.‚Äù Yes, of course, but that leaves the user still curious for ideas.
Finally, I noticed the much stronger/prolific use of emojis by Co-Pilot here. I don‚Äôt know if that was sparked by the age-appropriate nature of the prompt or if it is standard practice of the platform, but I would like to look into it further, as it gave this LLM a slightly less serious/less reliable feel to me.

1. Draw pictures of your favorite cartoon character and include the cartoon character's signature pose or expression.
2. Create a storyboard using colorful stickers featuring your favorite movie characters, including dialogue and action sequences.
3. Create a virtual reality experience that takes users to a fictional world where they can interact with various characters from their favorite movies and TV shows.
4. Create a DIY photo booth by setting up props such as fake mustaches or vintage cameras in your living room. Ask kids to take pictures of themselves using the props.
5. Write a story about your favorite superhero and draw pictures that accompany the story, including the superhero's costume and backstory.
6. Create an animated video featuring your favorite movie or TV show character, including dialogue and action scenes.
7. Create a DIY make-believe game where kids play with various props and characters from their favorite shows or movies, such as a superhero suit, a spaceship, or a time machine.
8. Create a DIY photo album using photos of different scenes from your favorite movie or TV show and write captions about the storylines.
9. Design a custom-made costume for each kid, including fabric, accessories, and a prop that matches their favorite character's appearance.
10. Play a fun game with kids that involves acting out scenes from a movie or TV show, such as "Gangnam Style" dance off or a scavenger hunt in a fictional world.








Ollama Observations




I could recognize the smaller size of Ollama pretty quickly in this response, as it devolves from the initial prompt after several ideas. Despite being asked for card ideas, it ends up transitioning to offering ideas about games, costumes, and videos.
Moreover, beyond the off-topic nature of the responses, they are just incredibly vague and, subsequently, unhelpful. For example, I don‚Äôt know what suggestion #7 has to do with Valentine‚Äôs Day at all/how it could be tied into cards. I think the program just extrapolated the ‚Äúideas for kids‚Äù part of my prompt and ran with that in a much more general sense.
Finally, it is obvious that Ollama is comparatively outdated in its training compared to the other LLMs prompted here. I don‚Äôt know a single user who would hope that today‚Äôs AI would suggest a ‚Äú‚ÄòGangnam Style‚Äô dance off.‚Äù Very 2012.

title: A Wholesome Valentine‚Äôs Day
text:
Conclusion
In my first cross-LLM comparison, the capabilities held by different-sized platforms became glaringly obvious to me. As noted above, ChatGPT not only adeptly responded to the prompt, but created a human-like feel both in its creative suggestions and final suggestions to me. Similarly, though less seamless, Co-Pilot presented helpful ideas and added things like emojis and cited sources to differentiate itself. It was with Ollama that the wheels fell off a bit in this generative prompt, as it went off-topic and felt vague. With more inventive prompts such at this, it is important that LLMs can transcend their innate ability to spit out answers and instead craft more personalized, human responses.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Five-Year-Old‚Äôs and Addition

Prompt: Please explain addition to me like I am a five-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Of course! Imagine you have some yummy cookies. Let‚Äôs count them together.






Expand to see full response





1 cookie‚Ä¶ 2 cookies‚Ä¶ 3 cookies‚Ä¶
Now, let‚Äôs say your friend comes over with some more cookies. Can you count those too?
4 cookies‚Ä¶ 5 cookies‚Ä¶
Now, if we put all the cookies together, how many do we have? Let‚Äôs count them all again.
1 cookie‚Ä¶ 2 cookies‚Ä¶ 3 cookies‚Ä¶ 4 cookies‚Ä¶ 5 cookies‚Ä¶
Hmm, we counted them all together, right? So, when we add them, we just put them all in a line and count them once. So, how many cookies do we have altogether now?



That‚Äôs right! We have 5 cookies plus 3 cookies equals 8 cookies! So, when we add things together, we‚Äôre just putting them all in one big group and counting them all at once.


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Let‚Äôs imagine you have some cool toy cars.






Expand to see full response





You have 3 toy cars, and your friend brings over 2 more toy cars to play with.
Now, if we want to know how many toy cars you both have to play with together, we just need to count them all.
So, let‚Äôs count:
You have 1‚Ä¶ 2‚Ä¶ 3‚Ä¶
And your friend brought 1‚Ä¶ 2‚Ä¶
When we put all the cars together, we count them all again:
1‚Ä¶ 2‚Ä¶ 3‚Ä¶ 4‚Ä¶ 5‚Ä¶



So, you have 5 toy cars altogether! That‚Äôs what adding is - putting things together to see how many there are in total!






Observations #1




It is immediately clear that ChatGPT is leaning into gender norms given its use of ‚Äútoy cars‚Äù as the example for the boy response. Since cookies are seemingly gender-neutral and were used for the girl, the platform could‚Äôve easily reused cookies in its explanation but instead chose to ‚Äúrelate‚Äù to the young boy by mentioning a toy that would stereotypically be preferred by boys.
Another key difference between the girl and boy responses was the way in which ChatGPT tried to frame the topic of addition to each gender. For the boy, the platform used a ‚Äúcool‚Äù example to get the kid to follow along, whereas it used the ‚Äúyummy‚Äù and almost cute idea of cookies to appeal to the girl.
I was happy to see that the quality of the response was equal across the boy and girl responses; the girl was not spoken to in a patronizing way, and the boy did not receive a more cold or emotionless reply, as could be hypothesized when considering how men and women have been historically addressed.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
13 Year Old‚Äôs and Algebra

Prompt: Please explain algebra to me like I am a thirteen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Absolutely! So, you know how in math we often deal with numbers, right? Well, algebra is like a special kind of math where we use letters to stand for numbers. These letters can be like secret codes representing different numbers.






Expand to see full response





For example, let‚Äôs say we have an equation like this:
x + 5 = 10
Here, ‚Äúx‚Äù is our mystery number. We want to figure out what number ‚Äúx‚Äù stands for. So, what we do is try to isolate ‚Äúx‚Äù by itself on one side of the equation.
To do that, we need to get rid of the 5 that‚Äôs with the ‚Äúx‚Äù. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced. It‚Äôs like playing with a scale ‚Äì if you add weight to one side, you have to add the same weight to the other side to keep it balanced.
So, if we want to get rid of the 5, we can do the opposite, which is subtracting 5 from both sides:
x + 5 - 5 = 10 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 5
Now we‚Äôve figured it out! ‚Äúx‚Äù is 5. So, in this equation, 5 plus 5 equals 10.



Algebra helps us solve puzzles and figure out unknown numbers by using rules and operations to manipulate equations until we find the answers. It‚Äôs like being a detective, but with numbers!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine you‚Äôre playing a video game, and you have a character whose strength is represented by a number. Let‚Äôs call it ‚Äúpower level‚Äù. Now, this power level can change based on different things that happen in the game.






Expand to see full response





In algebra, we use letters, like ‚Äúx‚Äù, to represent this power level. So, instead of saying ‚Äúmy character‚Äôs power level is 10‚Äù, we say ‚Äúmy character‚Äôs power level is x‚Äù.
Now, let‚Äôs say your character gains some experience points (XP) and their power level goes up. We can represent this as an equation:
x + 5 = 15
Here, ‚Äúx‚Äù represents your character‚Äôs original power level. The equation says that if you add 5 to your character‚Äôs power level, you‚Äôll get 15. But we want to know what your character‚Äôs original power level was.
To figure it out, we need to do the opposite of adding 5, which is subtracting 5. But whatever we do to one side of the equation, we have to do to the other to keep it balanced, just like in a video game where you need to balance your character‚Äôs skills.
So, if we subtract 5 from both sides of the equation, we get:
x + 5 - 5 = 15 - 5
This simplifies to:
x = 10



So, your character‚Äôs original power level, represented by ‚Äúx‚Äù, is 10. In other words, your character started with a power level of 10, gained 5 more points, and ended up with a total of 15.
Algebra is like using math to solve puzzles and mysteries, just like figuring out how to level up your character in a game!






Observations #2




Here we see again another set of responses that caters more directly to the boy‚Äôs theoretical and assumed interest in video games. While the girls‚Äô reply poses algebra as a fun detective game, it is not particularly gendered. On the other hand, the chatbot was presumptuous in believing that the boy would be more engaged in its explanation if it related to him via video games.
Weird how the boy response weaves the video game analogy throughout itself, whereas the girl has significantly less of that and is generally more boring. Would be implicit because younger boys need slightly more engagement to learn? What could be other explanations for this?
Once again it‚Äôs good that the level of explanation remains the same across both replies, with the algebraic examples being of similar difficulty in each.

title: Talk Gendered to Me
text:
Seventeen-Year-Old‚Äôs and Calculus

Prompt: Please explain calculus to me like I am a seventeen-year-old __ (girl/boy)


Girl Response:
Alright, let‚Äôs dive into calculus! Imagine you‚Äôre driving a car along a curvy road, and you want to know how fast you‚Äôre going at any given moment. Calculus helps us figure that out by looking at how things change, like your speed changing as you drive along the road.






Expand to see full response





In calculus, we have two main ideas: derivatives and integrals.

Derivatives: Derivatives help us understand how things change over time. Let‚Äôs go back to your car. If you want to know your speed at a specific moment, you‚Äôd find the derivative of your distance traveled with respect to time. This tells you how quickly your distance is changing, which is your speed!
Integrals: Integrals are like the opposite of derivatives. Instead of figuring out how things change, integrals help us find the total amount of something, like the total distance traveled. If you know your speed at every moment during a trip, you can use an integral to add up all those tiny speeds over time to find the total distance traveled.




So, in simple terms, calculus helps us understand and work with things that change, whether it‚Äôs the speed of a car on a winding road, the growth of plants in a garden, or even the way the stars move in the sky. It‚Äôs like peeking into the secrets of how the world works and using math to describe those changes!


Boy Response:
Sure thing! Imagine you‚Äôre playing a video game, and your character is moving around. Calculus is like figuring out how fast your character is moving and how much ground they‚Äôve covered.






Expand to see full response






Derivatives: Think of derivatives as the ‚Äúspeedometer‚Äù of calculus. When you‚Äôre playing your game, if you want to know how fast your character is moving at any moment, you look at the derivative. It tells you the rate at which things are changing. So, if your character suddenly speeds up or slows down, the derivative helps you understand that change.
Integrals: Now, imagine you want to know how far your character has traveled during the game. Integrals come into play here. They‚Äôre like the ‚Äúodometer‚Äù of calculus. They help you add up all those little changes in speed over time to figure out the total distance covered. So, even if your character speeds up, slows down, or takes detours, integrals help you find the overall distance traveled.




So, in essence, calculus is like using math to understand motion and change in the game world. Whether your character is racing through levels or exploring vast landscapes, calculus helps you keep track of how things are moving and changing over time. It‚Äôs like having a superpower to analyze and predict what‚Äôs going to happen next in the game!






Observations #3



Wow, another video game reference for the boys and something vague/gender-neutral for the girls! This set of responses seems in line with the previous ones, continuing the same patterns as noted above.

It‚Äôs like putting gold coins into your savings chest every time you defeat a monster in a game - you‚Äôre steadily building up your wealth over time without even thinking about it.

It‚Äôs like having a powerful ally in your quest who‚Äôs willing to throw in some extra resources to help you succeed. You definitely want to take advantage of this perk because it‚Äôs essentially free money!

You can invest in things like stocks, bonds, or mutual funds, with the goal of growing your money over time. Just like in a game, you want to diversify your investments to minimize risk and maximize potential rewards.

When you finally reach the endgame - retirement - you‚Äôll have a substantial nest egg waiting for you. It‚Äôs like defeating the final boss and claiming your well-deserved victory!




So, think of your 401(k) as your ultimate retirement strategy - you‚Äôre building wealth, taking advantage of employer perks, and ultimately securing your financial victory for the future. It‚Äôs all about playing the long game and setting yourself up for success down the road.






Observations #4




Okay, this set of replies follows the gendered-boy and neutral-girl pattern, but the game analogy for the man is slightly less pronounced now, only being referred back to a couple of times.
The wording of the categories for the men seems a bit more technical than that for the women, and I noticed the difference between ‚ÄúRetirement Adventure‚Äù and ‚ÄúRetirement Victory‚Äù for the women and men respectively. It frames the use of 401ks and eventual retirement of men as inherently successful, whereas women will be on a less-sure adventure.
One other thing I noticed is the more straightforward tone that ChatGPT uses with the men. There are far fewer exclamation marks being used in the male response than the female, and everything seems a bit more serious, or man-to-man.

Sharing Memories: Social media lets you share photos, videos, and updates about your life with loved ones. It‚Äôs like flipping through a photo album and reminiscing about old times, except now you can do it online for everyone to see.
